lg.l: The One Who rushed upon blossoms,
those united with His glorious feet

div.p: (i-ḷ). malariṉkaṇṇē ceṉṟavaṉatu māṭcimaippaṭṭa aṭikaḷaic cērntār ellāvulakiṟku mēlāya vīṭṭulakiṉkaṇ aḻiviṉṟi vāḻvār, (e-ṟu).

The meaning ... : Those who have joined [themselves to] the feet, which are in [a state of] greatness, of Him Who goes only upon blossoms, (will) live without perishing in heaven (lit. "the world of liberation"), which is above all the world (or: above all worlds?).

aṉpāṉiṉaivāratu uḷḷakkamalattiṉkaṇ avar niṉainta vaṭivōṭu viraintu cēṟaliṉ ‘ēkiṉāṉ’ eṉa iṟanta kālattāṟ kūṟiṉār; eṉṉai? “vārāk kālattu nikaḻuṅ kālattu, mōrāṅku varūum viṉaiccoṟ kiḷavi, yiṟanta kālattuk kuṟippoṭu kiḷattal, viraintaporuḷa veṉmaṉār pulavar”. eṉpa tōttākaliṉ. itaṉaip “pūmēṉaṭantāṉ” eṉpatōr peyarpaṟṟip piṟitōr kaṭavuṭ kēṟṟuvāru muḷar. cērtal—iṭaiviṭātu niṉaittal.

[In speaking?] of [His] going hastening over the lotuses that are the hearts (lit. "heart-lotuses"—a rūpaka compound in the manner of Sanskrit poetry) of those who contemplate Him with love with the feet that they contemplate, he has expressed [himself] using the past tense [in the verb] "hastened." Why? Because there is a chapter [of the Tolkāppiyam stating]: "The learned hold that, [when] expressing verbal expressions that [could] likewise occur in the future or in the present tense, with a [special] intention, [those expressions] have the sense of hastening." There are also worshippers of a certain other divinity [i.e. the Jina or Buddha?], who accept this—i.e.(?) "He Who walked upon flowers"—as one of his names. To unite [here means] to contemplate uninterruptedly.
i - ḷ:—malariṉmēl naṭantāṉatu māṭcimaippaṭṭa tiru vaṭiyaic cērntavaraṉrē, nilattiṉmēl neṭuṅkālam vāḻvār.
The meaning ... : They who have united with the holy feet, which are in greatness, of Him Who walked upon flowers—isn't it so!—live for a long time upon the world.
nilameṉṟu potuppaṭak kūṟiyavataṉāṉ, ivvulakiṉkaṇṇum mēlulakiṉkaṇṇum eṉṟukoḷḷappaṭum.
Because "world" has been said in a general way [i.e., without any further qualifier], one takes it to mean both "in this world" and "in the world above [i.e., heaven]."
‘toḻutāṟ payaṉ eṉṉai’ eṉṟārkkup pōkamnukartalum vīṭupeṟutalum eṉṟukūṟuvār, muṟpaṭap pōkam nukarvāreṉṟukūṟiṉar.

To those who ask, "What fruit [is gained] by worship?", [Tiruvaḷḷuvar will?] say that [it is] the enjoyment of experience (bhoga) and the obtainment of liberation; he has [here] expressed the enjoyment of experience first.
